This is probably the most unfairly judged movie based purely on its accolades. In reality, Crash has more value than any Oscarbait since 2004 in terms of "solving the racism" theme. Partially, of course, because Crash doesn't pretend it has answers or spend a bizarre amount of time moralizing. What's more important is that movies like Crash can not be made in today's environment. The unapologetic racism and insults would not fly in today's PC media sphere. Sure, it's overall message is as sappy as they come. The eternal woe that people cry about when it comes to race relations. If only we could place ourselves in each other's shoes. The movie, however, refuses to single out anyone in particular, and all the characters do indeed go through some kind of change. It is up to the viewers to decide whether it is fitting or even redeemed anyone of anything. 
The plot itself is a spaghetti of interconnectedness. It's full of set-ups and pay-offs. Some you can see a mile away. Some come as a genuine surprise. Several are silly in the matter of their presentation, for example Pena's one with the blanket. Apparently, filmmakers were proud of it enough to put the scene on the poster, but it's really laughably bad, from pacing to acting. Some of the characters feel left out, not getting enough screen time. Thandiwe Newton overacts in almost every scene.

With the subtlety and grace of a jackhammer, director Paul Haggis examines the thorny issue of race relations in Los Angeles.  The interwoven storylines and intriguing characters keep things interesting for a while, but the whole thing is so heavy-handed (practically all of the scenes either start or end with a racial conflict of some sort) and pedantic (virtually every scene preaches the same message – races need to understand and respect each other) that it eventually becomes a pretty significant chore to slog through its never-ending repetitiveness. While there are a handful of decent performances from the all-star cast, most of the film is sabotaged by the trite and predictable dialogue and the embarrassing performance of Matt Dillon as a racist police officer.  How this won the Oscar for best picture remains a baffling mystery almost twenty years later.

But co-writer/director Paul Haggis crafted a fascinating exploration of racism and bigotry in the City of Angels, the ways we can pre-judge each other and sometimes fail to see each other as human. The film is a plea for empathy, and while it may lack more nuance and complexity, it still finds ways to move us. A big part of that is the cast. All the players--save for a lightweight Brendan Fraser--are terrific. Standouts include Thandiwe Newton, Terrence Howard, and a volcanic Matt Dillon. So while it may not have been the best picture of 2005, it certainly was a provocative and emotional drama that got people talking.

Paul Haggis' two-hour episodic film shocked everyone at the 2006 Academy Awards when it won the top prize for Best Picture against the more highly rated Brokeback Mountain. Since that controversy, the thriller hasn't aged too well and is considered the biggest mistake in Academy history. Over the course of 48 hours, Crash follows fifteen residents of the US metropolis Los Angeles who have different social statuses. But they all have one thing in common: they are perpetrators and victims of widespread xenophobia, institutional racism and sexual assault.

As ambivalent as the film's plot may be, its broad-based ensemble is convincing all along the line. Each of the fifteen actors has his or her own story, which is told over many longer and shorter sequences. Particularly ambiguous is that of Matt Dillon's character Sergeant John Ryan. Actually a cold-blooded racist and obvious woman-molester, in private he is a son who cares for his sick father. He is aware of his cruelty and it seems as if he doesn't know any other way to help himself. The same is true of Ryan Phillippe as Officer Tom Hanson, a young police officer who at first doesn't understand his partner's actions towards black-skinned people before becoming prejudiced against this group himself. Terrence Howard and Thandie Newton, as an elite black couple, show what a traumatic event can do to you. They are seen in the most upsetting and volatile scenes, acting with great emotion and visible desperation. Chris Bridges and Don Cheadle are seen in very different roles, one keeping his head above water with criminal activities, while the other is a detective struggling with white supremacy in his profession and additional family problems. Although they never meet directly, the two have more in common than one might think. Michael Pena is protective as a family man struggling to make ends meet as a handyman in wealthy households and is the highlight of the film in one particular scene. Sandra Bullock and Brendan Fraser are an upper-class couple who, in all their self-absorption, experience moral lessons.  

First of all, it has to be said that Paul Haggis has good intentions with this film. He wants to present people with a realistic picture of the social situation in the USA, in which racism is clearly at the forefront, especially in connection with police violence. Other serious issues such as xenophobia, sexism and crime are also very much in focus. It doesn't read badly on paper, it just fails in its realisation. Without Haggi's handsome direction and the film's beautiful imagery, Crash would only be a below-average film. Some scenes are problematic and morally indefensible in the slightest. People are portrayed in a good light even though they don't deserve it. In addition, there is a lack of realism, which is an absolute necessity in a film with this theme. A stringing together of events in which all the characters at once demonstrate a connection? It may do justice to an episodic film, but that doesn't really add up to anything. Crash is a pretentious film that, despite a good premise and a fitting ensemble, has misconstrued its aim.

After an intoxicated Christine mouths off to Ryan, he subjects the couple to a body search. Ryan molests Christine in front of her husband and Hansen, who watches in disgust. Ryan releases them with a warning after Cameron apologizes. In the carjacked SUV, Anthony and Peter hit a Korean man while passing a parked van, dump him in front of a hospital, and drive away. Daniel's next call is to replace a lock at Farhad's shop, but when Daniel warns Farhad that the real problem is the door, Farhad won't listen. The next day, Farhad finds that his store has been wrecked and defaced with graffiti. Waters, while having sex with Ria, gets a phone call from his mother with dementia which leads to an argument about Ria's ethnicity. Waters later visits his mother, who asks him to find his missing younger brother. Ryan comes across a car accident and as he crawls into the overturned vehicle, he finds Christine trapped. Although she resists frantically at first, with the help of his partner and spectators, Ryan pulls the terrified Christine out just as her car bursts into flames. Police officers arrive on the scene and a chase ends with Cameron and Anthony in Cameron's car on a dead end residential street. Hansen is one of the pursuing officers and, out of guilt for the part he played in the assault of Cameron's wife, vouches for Cameron to be let off with a warning. Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "A raw and unsettling morality piece on modern angst and urban disconnect, Crash examines the dangers of bigotry and xenophobia in the lives of interconnected Angelenos." Roger Ebert gave the film 4/4 stars and described it as "a movie of intense fascination", listing it as the best film of 2005. The film also ranks at #460 in Empire's 2008 poll of the "500 Greatest Films of All Time". Some later reviews of Crash have been less favorable. Cultural critic Ta-Nehisi Coates criticized the film as shallow and "unthinking," naming Crash "the worst film of the decade." The film has been critiqued for depicting the Persian shopkeeper as a "deranged, paranoid individual who is only redeemed by what he believes is a mystical act of God." The film has also been criticized for using multicultural and sentimentalist imagery to cover over material and "historically sedimented inequalities" that continue to affect different racial groups in Los Angeles. In 2010, the Independent Film & Television Alliance selected Crash as one of the 30 Most Significant Independent Films of the last 30 years. The film can be used as an example of the so-called 'network narrative', a non-linear way of storytelling that highlights the contingency of life and values the structure of society over the individual. The disconnect and conflicts portrayed in the film are highlighted by its unusual structure and present the possibility of the portrayed racism and bigotry being a result of structural behaviour that partially neglects the individual perspective and creates an abstract scale.

Crash is another one of those movies that interweaves separate stories that have one or more settings, center on multiple themes, and explore invisible links between individuals. Most of the themes explore racism, crime, social interactions, and redemption. One story involves a Hispanic door handle repairman Daniel (Michael Peña) whose customer Farhad (Shaun Toub) has gone on a vengeful grudge against him when his shop has been vandalized and burgled. Another story, Jean (Sandra Bullock) and Rick (Brendan Fraser) file a report of their car being jacked by two criminals Anthony (Ludacris) and Peter (Larenz Tate) and become increasingly fearful of their lives. Yet another story, Peter's brother Detective Graham (Don Cheadle) and his partner Ria (Jennifer Esposito) investigate a hate crime involving a police officer who supposedly killed a black man. Still another thread, Officer John Ryan (Matt Dillon) searches for redemption as he rescues a woman Christine (Thandie Newton) from a burning car, that same woman whom he violated in front of her husband, a TV director Cameron (Terrence Howard), during interrogation the other night. Despite the brilliant match-cut editing, the terrific performances (particularly from Newton, Dillon, and Toub), and audacity to portray different angles of racism, the dialogue is hit-and-miss, ranging from clever to preachy and pretentious and, as mentioned before, the story structure is not unique, especially compared to other films like Intolerance, W.R. Mysteries of the Organism, and, most akin, Magnolia and Short Cuts. I wish Farhad wouldn't refer to every action around him to be an evil omen or Michael's daughter to be an ‘angel'. I know each story has to have a redemptive epiphany, but this child prophecy imagery is too cliched and sentimental and makes the writing more pretentious. For all its sins, Crash is still a decent brooding depiction of Los Angeles, but I've seen much better, more powerful and better written.

The first time I saw Crash was a week ago in my Social Issues in Film FYE class. My teacher told us to pay close attention to how the characters related to each other and try to find the deeper meaning in the film. The actors and directors did an amazing job.  They delivered a film that was transparent and hardcore, yet relevant and thought provoking.  By the end of the movie, I was completely blown away.  I did not expect to be so impressed by this film.  Surprisingly, it left me pondering my own personal views on several cultural and social issues.  I went back to my dorm that day a watched it over and over again.  The three things I look for when critiquing a film is a good story line, believable characters, and sensible plot execution. 
The story line of "Crash is about the collision of races, cultures, and classes." (Lisa Schwarzbaum, 2005). The pileup begins almost immediately when two young black men are walking in an upscale white part of Los Angeles and talking about the perception of young black men in upscale white town. Then carjacks a Lincoln Navigator that happens to belong to the L.A. district attorney and his rich-bitch wife and Bam!, that's four people linked and unmasked, in all their ugliest prejudices and most shameful fears, by the fate of one SUV which will eventually have everything, to do with the fate of another Navigator, owned by a rich black TV director and his wife and stopped for inspection by a racist white cop and his partner .When they got pulled over the cop touch the man's wife inappropriately in front of his very eyes. This atomically catches my attention at how in the film, Crash's main white characters are depicted in comfortable positions, both socially and economically. Then in another scene , the television executive producer who tells Black producer Cameron Thayer (Terence Howard)  to make one of his actors speak "more black" because that character was "supposed to be the dumb one."  In the movie most of the minority characters were portrayed as socially powerless. "The film Crash was directed by Paul Haggis, he does a good job at showing how most people feel prejudice and resentment against members of other groups, and observes the consequences of those feelings."(Roger Ebert, 2005) This I can completely agree with this because the director, didn't hold back when showing the audience the true reality behind the social issue of racism
For me, believing in the characters helps me gain a better understanding of the film.  Whether the characters are A-list or under budget actors / actress the way they express their emotions on camera plays a major role in creating a great film. The actors and actress in this are amazing from Sandra Bullock, Ludacris Jennifer Esposito, William Fichtner and many others. Their emotions poured out through the screen, I could feel everything they felt, whether it was anger, disappointment, shame, happiness,  sadness , although I couldn't fully relate to everything presented in the film , I  could easily put myself in their shoes , all from the way they made everything feel so realistic .The characters themselves function symbolically. For example, one thing that happens, again and again, is that peoples' assumptions prevent them from seeing the actual person standing before them. An Iranian is thought to be an Arab, although the Iranians are really Persian. Both the Iranian and the white wife of the district attorney believe a Mexican-American locksmith is a gang member and a crook; however he is a family man." No matter how hard some of the characters try to disprove their own racial stereotype, in some way or form it becomes inevitable that they must live out the stereotype to exist in the society they live in. " (Justin Aptaker, 2012) The characters find themselves not only stereotyping others but also living up to their stereotypes The movie Crash is unique because instead of showing characters at their best, like most popular movies do, the characters are instead stressed out and pushed to their own emotional limits.
If the film gets my critical and perceptive juices flowing, then it generally works for me. I want the film to leave me with something to think about. This film constantly keeps you on your toes and at the edge of your seat. There is always a twist. Everyone's life stories tie into one another rand you watch at how their actions influences not only their life but someone's life. The film sets a tone of how reality truly is this and that these things really happened. The characters in the film took me on a ride of crazy emotions, yet it managed teaches me to realize that it is never too late to redeem one's self and change. In the film there is a lack of acceptance of other cultures and unwillingness to understand why individuals are the way they are. Crash demonstrates this throughout the film through every character. This is the part of the film that made me pounder on the deeper meanings and the main point the director was trying translate.
Ultimately, I believe anyone seeing it is likely to be moved to have a little more sympathy for people not like themselves. "Crash" exceeded my expectations it had a relevant story line, believable characters and a thought provoking message. The movie contained hurt, coldness and cruelty, but it still leaves you feeling hopeful. In the end, the movie conveys the importance of respecting individuality, and realizing we share similar fears and hopes. You may have to look hard to see it, but "Crash" is a film about making personal progress in the midst of unexpected pain.

The movie Crash is about the daily struggle against prejudice and racism in America. It starts off with several seemingly unrelated stories, which ultimately converge into a single crash after much deliberation. Although the clash may appear coincidental and even contrite at first, at a deeper level, the movie seems to suggest that there is no absolute coincidence, that the black guy shot in a car could as well be your lost brother, that the police officer teasing you in the last moment could as well be your savior, and that the person who insists on justice could as well be a murderer. None of the accidents should be surprising, since they are simply manifestations of the historical racism and cultural prejudice of America on a daily basis. Yet what really distinguishes Crash from other conventional movies that portray racism is the reconciliation part at the epilogue. Indeed, certain people may appear offensive upon first glance, yet the life stories behind them could be so sympathetic as well. All it needs to understand a person more holistically is to go a layer deeper, beyond what his deeds may suggest. Above everything, Crash is about contradiction, contradiction between people's surface and their hidden nature, between what a man has done and what he will do, between what things seem and what they actually are. At the end, the movie suggests that because people do change over time, racial stereotypes and even personal characterization can't always apply, yet love and compassion, the beauty of humanity, shall always persist and find their way in darkness.  

Although the movie depicts racism mostly in the lights of average Americans, one scene particularly mesmerizing is when the wretched Chinese are released from the car by the black fellow. On the one hand, this scene greatly resembles the enfranchisement of black men in the 19th century, the only difference being Abraham Lincoln is a black man this time. From a historical perspective, this ending points out the continuum of oppression and liberation in America, and how much progress America has made and unmade since the Declaration of Independence. On the other hand, when the trafficked Chinese step outside of the car, they look isolated, dismantled and lost. Yet the reason for their deliria is not just the fact that they don't mentally belong here. The reality is that the world immediately in front of them is so stereotypically diverse and grotesquely prosperous that it elicits fear. In the 21st century, what America really needs is to not only solve the domestic issues of racism, but also accommodate immigrants against any form of nativism.

While CRASH is most assuredly a technically well-made film, there is absolutely nothing it has to say that couldn't be ascertained from paying a little attention in the real world. Racism is definitely a problem in America (and the world), but all this film seems to have to contribute to that discussion is that it's bad. To make matters worse, every single character in the film is a stereotype. And there's also too many characters to begin with. You learn a little bit about them and their lives, but the running time didn't really allow for a deeper examination of these people and why they are the way they are. All of the performances were good, to be sure, but it was all in service of a heavy-handed script that approaches the issue of racism in the most skin-deep way possible. Despite the film's title, implying a certain degree of chance in one's encounters, every moment in the film felt calculated and calibrated for maximum emotional impact in a way that undermines the seriousness of the issues it wanted to address. At the end, no one really learns anything and, as an audience member, I was left wondering what the point was exactly. From a technical standpoint, though, the film is fairly solid. The movie is about, and (presumably) shot in, LA and the filmmakers did a good job of capturing it on film, especially in the night time. The cinematography was actually kind of beautiful, in contrast to the ugliness of the characters. I'll even give credit to the score for being relatively toned down, letting the rigged emotional stakes of the film stand out that much more. When all is said and done, I'm also left wondering how in the world this shallow nonsense ever won Best Picture. Although well-made and well-acted, it just seems like the Academy gave themselves a pat on the back for even acknowledging that racism exists. The subject deserves better and more thorough treatment than it got with this film.

A worthy 'Best Picture' winner, 'Crash' is an unsuspecting masterpiece that looks at the hard truths of racial disparity in post-9/11 Los Angeles. There are so many factors at play in the Paul Haggis directed film, which boasts a multifaceted, talented cast (Brendan Fraser, Sandra Bullock, Terrence Howard, Thandie Newton, Ryan Phillippe, Don Cheadle, Matt Dillon, Jennifer Esposito), that it's hard to keep track of all the individual stories that are featured, although it's genius how they are all sewn together as the film progresses. Even though there are deep topics at the center of the film, the characters portrayed are very identifiable, and it's interesting to see how feelings change about certain characters over the course of the film. What 'Crash' really excels at is its ability to introduce thought-provoking questions that stay with you long after watching the plot unfold onscreen. To add to things, there are no issues with pacing, and the film easily keeps your attention, which is something a lot of dramas have trouble with in this day and age. Despite its heaviness and subject matter, 'Crash' is an enjoyable film that offers as many teachable moments as it does entertaining moments.

Crash--or more appropriately, "2 Degrees of Separation: The World's Angriest Racists"--is a load of Oscar bait fluff.  While racism is an important issue to address, so is verisimilitude in a screenplay, and Crash disservices worthy movie material.  Overall, Crash proves to be a poorly constructed story with too many characters whose lives are intertwined by a series of implausibly tragic miscues, each ultimately reshaping the respective bigoted worldviews. And while Crash isn't all bad--there are some decent performances to be salvaged--it is predominantly an over-blown, pretentious piece of crap.

No one can ever sit down to view this movie and be able to fully prepare themselves for what awaits them in this jolting, raw, and sometimes angering work from Paul Haggis. It packs one honest punch after another, successfully creating an uncomfortable (and rightly so) look at racism. Yet even in its intensity, the tiniest flicker of hope resides. Crash is, in all senses of the word, a masterpiece.

If the film had never won the Best Picture Oscar in 2006 (over Brokeback Mountain, which everyone considered a 100% certain winner), it would have been quickly forgotten. But ever since the visibly surprised Jack Nicholson announced it as the winner, many people have denounced it as the worst film of the decade and the worst film to ever win the award. Even in 2010s they still keep reminding us what a self-indulgent, pseudo-profound and sentimental piece of crap it was.
 
Crash has numerous storylines and characters, all surrounding the subject of racism. During 36 hours, various people in Los Angeles, including a black cop, an Iranian shopkeeper, a Hispanic locksmith, two black carjackers and a wealthy district attorney and his ever-querulous wife among others, get in touch with multiculturalism, xenophobia and their own prejudices.
 
I do acknowledge the flaws of Crash, which are many. One thing it was particularly criticized for was being preachy. It isn't that all the time, but it has moments when you feel like the message is shoved down your throat. Some of the dialogue is very heavy-handed and exaggerated and some plot points forced. And sometimes it slips to sentimentality and even feels like a soap opera.

But Crash is not a bad film. In fact, it's pretty damn good. Why? Because no matter how many faults you find from it, no matter how self-important, soapy and sentimental it may be, it does provoke thoughts and feelings. It drills deep down to the nature of prejudices, and bravely tackles on the prevalence and everyday nature of racism. It may not be a politically correct film. It deals with questions of racism directly and straight out, forcing the viewers also to ponder their own attitude towards different people.

And what Haggis really succeeds at is creating character portraits. He refuses to make any of them a stereotype or a caricature. You learn to care about the characters and their fates, no matter how unpleasant some of them may seem at first. For example, Matt Dillon's character, a policeman John Ryan, is at first shown as a racist prick, as he sexually harasses Thandie Newton's character and forces her husband to watch, but later we see him feeling anguish over his sick father, and we understand why he did such an obscene thing. The two carjackers are at first shown as one-dimensional, stereotypical hoppers, but the other one of them is apparently religious, and the other one has a surprise for us at the very end of the film. There isn't a clear protagonist in the film, and some of the characters get less screen time than others, but we can still clearly understand who they are and what their lives are like.

The film is quite cynical in demonstrating peoples' attitude towards strangers, indicating that they're always suspecting the worst about each other. But it also believes in an individual's ability to change. Many critics have asserted that the film uses an overly complex story and large character gallery to deliver a simplistic message ("racism is bad"), but there is much more below the surface; the film paints a very complex picture about human nature.

Some of the characters and situations where they learn something feel awkward; like the Iranian shopkeeper, who is mostly shown as an incredulous, hysterical, impolite freak, who learns to be more confiding and peaceful only after accidentally shooting a little girl. And it's very hard to believe that Ryan and his partner, would end up meeting the couple that Ryan embarrassed the next day in their respective situations. But these unconvincing scenes have such dramatic tension that you don't pay attention to their improbability.

The film is also well shot by J. Michael Muro, but the true star here is the editor Hughes Winborne, who carries the story (or stories) on so fluently that you aren't confused at any point. The transitions from one story to another are completely seamless, and we always get to spend the right amount of time with one character before going on to the next. Mark Isham's score is also impressive; sometimes it's frustratingly underlining but mostly very beautiful.

The performances of Crash range from terrific to plain silly. The best performances come from Matt Dillon (who also received an Oscar nomination), who is truly spooky as Ryan, who has problems to control his own prejudices, and Don Cheadle, who is very convincing as a cop looking for his criminal brother. Terrence Howard and Thandie Newton are also really good as the black couple. Keith David has only a brief role, but delivers a nice, smooth performance as a police lieutenant. Chris Bridges, better known as the rapper Ludacris, is also pretty good, while you could expect him to be absolutely terrible, as musicians who become actors often are.

However, there are some weaker performances as well. Sandra Bullock is still not convincing, even though she's clearly trying to find a new dimension from herself as an actor. Ryan Phillippe is too inexpressive in his role as Ryan's partner, and Brendan Fraser is totally wooden. But Bullock's and Fraser's characters are some of the most irrelevant of the film, so it's obvious they can't get much out of them. They are also the characters you care about the least.

Overall Crash is a film that deserves to be seen and thought about. Sure it has flaws and isn't a masterpiece that will stick in your mind forever, but it's a solid, well written, well directed and mostly well acted drama. Did it deserve to win the Best Picture Oscar or not? Who knows, moreover, who cares? The awards are a side issue. Haggis has made the film with good intentions, hoping to make people think and discuss the subject matter, and even if you find the end result clumsy, it's always better to have a story with at least some thought in it than a story left untold, right? I like Crash. I think it's a good film. And I'm not ashamed to admit it.

I was looking forward to my long-delayed viewing of Paul Haggis' Crash. I thought it would provide me with an experience along the lines of when I watched Falling Down, a breathtaking portrayal of societal arrogance, where I was riveted and infuriated for much of the film. Instead, Crash is a by-the-numbers film about America being a melting pot of racists, waiting to be set off in a cliche set up, and appears to be more of a stock lecture instead of a truly eye-opening film.

I must give respect and well-earned shock to the film for winning Best Picture, over critic/fan favorite, Brokeback Mountain. Its win was probably one of the biggest stuns next to when Annie Hall bested Star Wars in 1977, or when Forrest Gump stomped both Pulp Fiction and The Shawshank Redemption for the same title in 1994. Crash is definitely an interesting piece, setting its sights on the controversial nature of racism and its victims and alarmists, but manages to plod along in its runtime, rarely reaching heights of admirable status, and manages to be questionably exploitative and, dare I say, racist in itself.

The film follows numerous characters in a forty-eight hour period in Los Angeles where they are met with racial confrontations, have their personal outlooks and insights tested, and eventually, have their stories intertwined with one another in some way, shape or form, connected by the central focus; a car crash. Such characters are a black LAPD officer (Don Cheadle) who is long estranged from his mother, a white District Attorney (Brendan Fraser) and his spoiled-rotten wife (Sandra Bullock) whose car was hijacked by two young black men (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges and Larenz Tate), a racist white police officer (Matt Dillon), who molests a black woman (Thandie Newton) right in front of her husband (Terrence Howard), a Hispanic locksmith (Michael Pena) trying to keep his family business straight, an uptight Persian immigrant (Shaun Toub), and an optimistic cop (Ryan Phillippe), who works with Matt Dillon's character.

Right off the bat, there are far too many underdeveloped characters here. The way we are greeted with them is awkward, too fast, and lacks much substance. In an ordinary anthology film with intertwining characters, take Adam Rifkin's criminally underrated and near-perfect film, LOOK for example, we spend enough time to get to know the characters, form opinions about them, and actually become intrigued and somewhat astonished at how they meet and engage with one another. Crash breathlessly tries to juggle a dozen loose stories and find creative ways for them to connect with each other that it doesn't have time to adapt its subjects into believable people. It's almost encouraging its own problem by stereotyping its characters.

The film portrays all of its characters as on-the-edge racists triggered by a fairly mild, forgivable, and misunderstood circumstance where every conclusion is jumped to and nobody is smart enough to think something over before acting. Perhaps Crash is trying to show us that that, specifically, is the problem, but it is gone about in such a ham-fisted, heavy-handed way that we know what the film is trying to say, but we simply don't care and are tired of being talked down to for close to two hours.

With that being said, it must too be stated that all the actors here do a wonderful job at, at least, trying to create versatile, believable characters, although few succeed. Sandra Bullock is the standout here, simply giving it her all and showing us true character-acting versatility in not only her role-choices, but her creative and involved performances. Ludacris isn't as outgunned as I thought he'd be, Don Cheadle does exceptional work, Matt Dillon is great here, and so is the rest of the cast. But inevitably, I'm reminded of the one-dimensional characters they play and the truly vacuous background that plagues each and every one of them. A quick look at other reviewers scattered across the internet show that their shallowness has neglected people to notice the good acting behind them.

The film concludes with one of the lamest, most uncreative Hollywood endings in a blue moon, showing us easily the most schmaltzy, conventional, unbelievable, cringe-inducing ending a film about racism could possible give us. Even with dedicated performances from a barrage of different talents, Crash connects their characters' stories in such a contrived and facile way it's distracting, is plagued by levels of sheer incredulity, and occupies an end scene of complete and total folderol. As a whole, it plays like a heavy-handed lecture by a representative of the "Why Can't We All Just Get Along?" committee.

Starring: Sandra Bullock, Don Cheadle, Matt Dillon, Jennifer Esposito, Brendan Fraser, Terrence Howard, Chris "Ludacris" Bridges, Thandie Newton, Ryan Phillippe, Larenz Tate, Shaun Toub, and Michael Peña. Directed by: Paul Haggis.
